thread.title: George Michael's Range Rover goes up for sale on eBay
thread.title_full: George Michael's Range Rover goes up for sale on eBay

title: George Michael's Range Rover goes up for sale on eBay
text: Share this article Share The seller said the Range Rover was one of two bought at the time, with the second being the car Michael crashed into a lorry on the A34 in Berkshire in 2009. They continued: 'Obviously this vehicle is a piece of pop history and is part of a very turbulent time in George's life. It can be seen in lots of pictures online with George.' 'Good condition': The seller said the Range Rover was one of two bought at the time by Michael The car is said to be 'a piece of pop history' and part of a 'very turbulent time' in the star's life After Michael was found dead last year, dozens of messages for him were stuck to the Snappy Snaps store where he crashed in Hampstead, North London. Several messages were stuck to the front of the store as it became an unlikely pilgrimage for fans, but a sign was later placed outside asking them to stop. After pleading guilty to driving under the influence over the crash in 2010, Michael was sentenced to two months in prison. The singer, whose real name is Georgios Panayiotou, was initially taken to HMP Pentonville in London, where former inmates included Oscar Wilde and Boy George. 'Wham': Michael drove his Range Rover into the front of this Snappy Snaps branch in Hampstead, North London, in July 2010 while under the influence of drugs Damage: After pleading guilty to driving under the influence over the crash in Hampstead in 2010, Michael was sentenced to two months in prison Later, he gave a 'sincere' apology to store manager John while live on-air on the Capital FM breakfast show when host Johnny Vaughan called him. Michael said at the time: 'I'm genuinely and sincerely sorry for smashing into your shop.' Taking the apology in good nature, John replied: 'That's no problem. It would be nice if you could come through the front door one day soon.' The eBay listing was revealed by Sun reporters Gemma Mullin and John Shammas. Read more: Share or comment on this article 28
